# Lens speed

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/f/fa/Lensspeed.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lensspeed.jpg)

A fast prime (fixed focal length) lens, the Canon 50mm f/1.4 (left), and a
slower zoom lens, the Canon 18–55mm f/3.5–5.6 (right); this lens is faster at
18mm than it is at 55mm.

Main article: [Aperture](/wiki/Aperture "Aperture")

**Lens speed** refers to the maximum [aperture](/wiki/Aperture "Aperture")
diameter, or minimum [f-number](/wiki/F-number "F-number"), of a [photographic
lens](/wiki/Photographic_lens "Photographic lens"). A lens with a larger
maximum aperture (that is, a smaller minimum f-number) is called a "fast lens"
because it can achieve the same exposure with a faster [shutter
speed](/wiki/Shutter_speed "Shutter speed"). Conversely, a smaller maximum
aperture (larger minimum f-number) is "slow" because it delivers less light
intensity and requires a slower (longer) shutter speed.

A fast lens speed is desirable in taking pictures in dim light, or with long
[telephoto](/wiki/Telephoto "Telephoto") lenses and for controlling [depth of
field](/wiki/Depth_of_field "Depth of field") and [bokeh](/wiki/Bokeh
"Bokeh"), especially in portrait photography,[1] and for [sports
photography](/wiki/Sports_photography "Sports photography") and
[photojournalism](/wiki/Photojournalism "Photojournalism").

Lenses may also be referred to as being "faster" or "slower" than one another;
so an [f/3.5](/wiki/F-number "F-number") lens can be described as faster than
an f/5.6.

## Tradeoffs[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lens_speed&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Tradeoffs")]

Attaining maximum lens speed requires engineering tradeoffs, and as such,
"[prime](/wiki/Prime_lens "Prime lens")" (fixed focal length) lenses are
generally faster than [zoom lenses](/wiki/Zoom_lens "Zoom lens"), and modern
manual-focus lenses are generally faster than their autofocus counterparts.[2]

With 35mm cameras, the fastest lenses are typically in the "[normal
lens](/wiki/Normal_lens "Normal lens")" range near 50mm and there are several
high-quality fast lenses available that are relatively inexpensive. For
example, the [Canon EF 50mm f/1.8 II](/wiki/Canon_EF_50mm_f/1.8_II "Canon EF
50mm f/1.8 II") or [Nikon AF Nikkor 50mm
f/1.8D](/wiki/Nikon_AF_Nikkor_50_mm_f/1.8D "Nikon AF Nikkor 50 mm f/1.8D") are
very inexpensive, but quite fast and optically well-regarded. Old fast manual
focus lenses, just as the Nikkor-S(C) or Nikkor AI-S 50mm f/1.4, were
historically produced abundantly, and are thus sold relatively inexpensively
on the used lens market.

Especially outside of the "normal lenses", lens speed also tends to correlate
with the price and/or quality of the lens. This is because lenses with larger
maximum apertures require greater care with regard to design, precision of
manufacture, special coatings and quality of glass. At wide apertures,
[spherical aberration](/wiki/Spherical_aberration "Spherical aberration")
becomes more significant and must be corrected. Faster
[telephoto](/wiki/Telephoto "Telephoto") and wide-angle
[retrofocus](/wiki/Retrofocus "Retrofocus") designs tend to be much more
expensive.

## Fast lenses[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lens_speed&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Fast lenses")]

The fastest lenses in general production now are f/1.2 or f/1.4, with more at
f/1.8 and f/2.0, and many at f/2.8 or slower. What is considered "fast" has
evolved to lower f-numbers over the years, due to advances in [lens
design](/wiki/Lens_design "Lens design"), [optical
manufacturing](/wiki/Optical_manufacturing "Optical manufacturing"), quality
of glass, [optical coatings](/wiki/Optical_coating "Optical coating"), and the
move toward smaller imaging formats. For example, the [1911 Encyclopædia
Britannica](/wiki/1911_Encyclop%C3%A6dia_Britannica "1911 Encyclopædia
Britannica") states that "...[Lenses] are also sometimes classified according
to their rapidity, as expressed by their effective apertures, into extra
rapid, with apertures larger than f/6; rapid, with apertures from f/6 to f/8;
slow, with apertures less than f/11."

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Canon_85mm_comparison_%28front%29.jpg/250px-
Canon_85mm_comparison_%28front%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Canon_85mm_comparison_\(front\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Canon_85mm_comparison_\(front\).jpg "Enlarge")

[Canon 85mm f/1.8 and f/1.2](/wiki/Canon_EF_85mm_lens "Canon EF 85mm lens")
showing their large [entrance pupils](/wiki/Entrance_pupil "Entrance pupil")

For scale, note that f/0.5, f/0.7, f/1.0, f/1.4, and f/2.0 are each 1 f-stop
apart (2× as fast), as an f-stop corresponds to a factor of [square root of
2](/wiki/Square_root_of_2 "Square root of 2"), about 1.4. Thus around f/1.0, a
change of 0.1 corresponds to about 1/4 of an f-stop (by [linear
approximation](/wiki/Linear_approximation "Linear approximation")): f/1.0 is
about 50% faster than f/1.2, which is about 50% faster than f/1.4.

As of
2017[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Lens_speed&action=edit),
Canon, Nikon, Pentax and Sony all make an autofocus 50mm f/1.4 lens. These are
not unusual lenses and are relatively inexpensive. Canon also makes autofocus
50mm and 85mm f/1.2 lenses, while Nikon makes a manual focus 50mm f/1.2 lens
and an autofocus 85mm f/1.4; see [Canon EF 50mm
lenses](/wiki/Canon_EF_50mm_lens "Canon EF 50mm lens") and [Canon EF 85mm
lenses](/wiki/Canon_EF_85mm_lens "Canon EF 85mm lens") for details. Pentax
makes a 50mm f/1.4 lens and 55mm f/1.4 lens for [APS-C](/wiki/APS-C "APS-C")
cameras; see [Pentax lenses](/wiki/Pentax_lenses "Pentax lenses"). Sony makes
a 50mm f/1.4 lens which is a continuation of the [Minolta AF 50mm f/1.4
lens](/wiki/Minolta_AF_50mm_f/1.4_lens "Minolta AF 50mm f/1.4 lens"), and two
lenses with Carl Zeiss: a 50mm f/1.4 and 85mm f/1.4.

The maximum [exposure time](/wiki/Exposure_time "Exposure time") in free-hand
photography can be enhanced even more also for fast lenses, if the camera is
equipped with an [image stabilisation](/wiki/Image_stabilisation "Image
stabilisation") system. In 2014 [Panasonic](/wiki/Panasonic "Panasonic")
introduced the fastest lens with in-built stabilisation, the
[Leica](/wiki/Leica_Camera "Leica Camera") [Nocticron](/wiki/Nocticron
"Nocticron") 42.5 mm f/1.2, which in the meantime even can be operated with
dual image stabilisation (Dual I.S.), provided that the camera body has an
additional [stabilising system at the image
sensor](/wiki/Image_stabilization#Sensor-shift "Image stabilization"), too.

In the mid 60s there was something of a fad for fast lenses among the major
manufacturers.[3] In 1966 in response to the trend [Carl
Zeiss](/wiki/Carl_Zeiss "Carl Zeiss") displayed a prop lens christened the
Super-Q-Gigantar 40mm f/0.33 at [photokina](/wiki/Photokina_1966 "Photokina
1966").[3] Made from various parts found around the factory (the lenses came
from a [darkroom condenser enlarger](/wiki/Enlarger#Types_of_Enlarger
"Enlarger")), the claimed speed and focal lengths were purely nominal and it
wasn't usable for photography.[3][4]

### Maximum possible
speed[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lens_speed&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Maximum possible speed")]

Ultimately, the speed of a lens is limited by mechanical constraints of the
camera system (shutter or mirror clearance, [mount](/wiki/Lens_mount "Lens
mount") diameter). The smallest possible [working f-number](/wiki/Working_f-
number "Working f-number") is

     N min = 1 2 N A max = 1 2 n sin ⁡ θ {\displaystyle N_{\text{min}}={\frac {1}{2\;\mathrm {NA} _{\text{max}}}}={\frac {1}{2\,n\sin \theta }}} ![N_{\\text{min}}={\\frac {1}{2\\;\\mathrm {NA} _{\\text{max}}}}={\\frac {1}{2\\,n\\sin \\theta }}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e77288bc3a6fce874f67e9afda1ccb03be18d916)

where

  * NAmax is the largest possible [numerical aperture](/wiki/Numerical_aperture "Numerical aperture"),
  * n is the [index of refraction](/wiki/Index_of_refraction "Index of refraction") of the medium behind the lens, most often air where n = 1,
  * θ is the half-angle of the maximum cone of light that can reach the film or sensor.

This sets a limit close to f/1.0 to f/1.2 for most [SLR](/wiki/Single-
lens_reflex_camera "Single-lens reflex camera") mounts, whereas lenses for
[rangefinder](/wiki/Rangefinder_camera "Rangefinder camera") and
[mirrorless](/wiki/Mirrorless_camera "Mirrorless camera") cameras can be
faster, as they can be brought closer to the image plane. Reproduction lenses
incapable of infinity focus can have nominal f-numbers smaller than this
limit, as the limit applies to the _working_ f-number (the f-number corrected
by the [bellows factor](/wiki/Bellows_\(photography\) "Bellows
\(photography\)")), not to the nominal f-number. It should be noted that only
the working f-number correctly assesses the light gathering power of the lens.

Since sin θ < 1, it follows that no lens can be faster than f/0.5 if it
operates in air. Lenses can be made faster than this by requiring the film
emulsion to be in physical contact with the rear element, thus eliminating the
air gap between the lens and the emulsion. Another option is to use [oil
immersion](/wiki/Oil_immersion "Oil immersion") techniques.

### List of ultrafast
lenses[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lens_speed&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: List of ultrafast lenses")]

Some of the fastest camera lenses in production as of
2017[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Lens_speed&action=edit)
were as follows:

  * Handevision Ibelux 40mm f/0.85, Made for multiple camera mounts including Micro 4/3, Sony E-Mount and Fujifilm X-Mount

  * [Cosina Voigtländer](/wiki/Cosina_Voigtl%C3%A4nder "Cosina Voigtländer") Nokton 17.5mm f/0.95 Aspherical [Micro Four Thirds](/wiki/Micro_Four_Thirds_system "Micro Four Thirds system") mount[5][6][7]
  * [Cosina Voigtländer](/wiki/Cosina_Voigtl%C3%A4nder "Cosina Voigtländer") Nokton 25mm f/0.95 [Micro Four Thirds](/wiki/Micro_Four_Thirds_system "Micro Four Thirds system") mount[6][8]
  * [Cosina Voigtländer](/wiki/Cosina_Voigtl%C3%A4nder "Cosina Voigtländer") Nokton 42.5mm f/0.95 [Micro Four Thirds](/wiki/Micro_Four_Thirds_system "Micro Four Thirds system") mount[6][9]
  * [Leica](/wiki/Leica_Camera "Leica Camera") Noctilux-M 50mm f/0.95 ASPH announced on September 15, 2008, it is one of the fastest [aspherical lens](/wiki/Aspherical_lens "Aspherical lens") to have ever reached mass production, with a MSRP of £6290 (approximately US$10,000).[10]
  * SLR Magic HyperPrime LM 50mm T0.95 (f/0.92)
  * [Noktor](/wiki/Noktor "Noktor") 50mm f/0.95 'HyperPrime'[11] a fast CCTV lens design adapted for the [Micro Four Thirds system](/wiki/Micro_Four_Thirds_system "Micro Four Thirds system")[12]
  * SLR Magic 25mm T/0.95
  * SLR Magic 35mm T/0.95
  * [Mitakon 50mm](/wiki/Shenyang_Zhongyi_Mitakon_Speedmaster_50_mm_f/0.95 "Shenyang Zhongyi Mitakon Speedmaster 50 mm f/0.95") and 35mm f/0.95
  * Vantage One T/1.0 Cine lenses - 17.5mm to 120mm Super35mm Spherical Primes.
  * Metabones 0.58x BMPCC Speed Booster (for Blackmagic Pocket Cinema Camera) combined with an f/1.2 SLR lens to yield f/0.74 or combined with an f/1.4 SLR lens to yield f/0.80 [13]
  * Metabones 0.64x Speed Booster XL (for Micro Four Thirds format) combined with an f/1.2 SLR lens to yield f/0.80 or combined with an f/1.4 SLR lens to yield f/0.90[14]
  * Metabones 0.71x Speed Booster ULTRA (for either Micro Four Thirds or APS-C formats) combined with an f/1.2 SLR lens to yield f/0.90 or combined with an f/1.4 SLR lens to yield f/1.0[15][16]

qa.question: what does the speed of a lens mean
qa.answer: ['maximum aperture diameter, or minimum f-number, of a photographic lens. A lens with a larger maximum aperture (that is, a smaller minimum f-number)']
